Gradually stir in cornflour slurry until sauce is thick enough to "coat the back of a spoon". Don't overdo it, and likely won't need to use the entire slurry. Can add more later after adding beef.
Add beef and green parts of spring onions and toss for 30 seconds. Aiming for almost all of the sauce to now be coating the other ingredients, rather than pooling.

Diary.Content: Bought beef at Uncles Butcher in Eastwood. Did a scant 1/3 cup soy sauce instead of 1/4 cup. Added some more corn flour slurry after adding the beef and it was fine. Was still some liquid left, no problems. Beef took more like 2-3 min per side until it got properly hot.
Next time I make this, I should try a totally different looking recipe, here: https://www.onionringsandthings.com/mongolian-beef/#wprm-recipe-container-14557.
Starting now, plan is to do it same as last time I think.
Using only 3 spring onions.
Making rice like way later than the recipe suggests.
Doing 0.25 cup rather than the 1/3 I used by accident last time.
Probably did a little extra ginger
The dredging begins.
No way I'm putting all that oil in a pan at once, gonna measure by tablespoons. oh, the dredging is done
Beef did take 1 min per side, excluding time to take it out and put it in and lay it out and all. Giving sauce an extra min or two.
done.
Tasted good, not as mind blowing as I remembered. Yields like 3 hungry serves.

Recipes.Name: Samosas
Recipes.Note: From \href{https://www.cookwithmanali.com/samosa-recipe/#wprm-recipe-container-43459}{Cook with Manali}, and I'm suspicious of how similar the Recipe Tin Eats version is to Manali's. Adding water to the filling mixture is an adjustment suggested by Sunil at Sunil's Spice Centre after reading over the recipe. This recipe is so extremely involved and takes so long, and doesn't make a lot. It's a special occasion food, the result is delightful but it takes so much work. The samosas are fried on low heat initially or else the pastry bubbles in a not very cute way. Adjust frying temperature if it isn't working, I should have taken more notes.

Steps.Content: Mix flour, salt and caraway seeds in a bowl.
Push @4 tbsp vegetable oil into the flour mixture with your fingers for 4 minutes until consistency is like crumbs and a pressed clump doesn't fall apart. Don't underdo it.
Add @7 tbsp water gradually, mixing until a it is a stiff dough. Don't overwork it.
Cover dough with a damp teatowel and sit for 40 minutes.
Now for the filling. Boil the potatoes, drain and mash very lightly.
Finely chop ginger.
Heat @2 tbsp oil in a large pan on medium-high. Add cumin seeds, fennel seeds and coriander seeds. Fry for a 15 seconds.
Add diced ginger and hing to pan and mix. Fry for 1 minute.
Add potatoes and peas to pan, mix well. Add water to adjust consistency.
Add coriander powder, garam masala, amchur, and salt. Mix and then remove from heat to cool.
Make a water and flour slurry in a small cup, just mix a little of each until it feels vaguely gluey.
Now to shape them. Knead the dough a little, then split into @7 pieces. Roll each piece out into a circle 15cm in diameter, and cut each circle in half, leaving you with 14 semicircles.
Dipping a finger into the slurry, apply it along the straight edge of the semicircle. Press into a cone, pinching the end to form a point.
Holding the cone in one hand like you would a tiny icecream cone, add 1-2 tbsp of filling. Apply the slurry along the top edges and press them together to seal. Repeat for each piece of dough.
Now to fry them. Fill a medium saucepan with vegetable oil and heat on stove to 130 degrees. To test heat, drop a small piece of dough in and it should take a few seconds to come to the surface.
Gently lower 5 samosas into the pot and fry for 10 minutes.
Raise the heat to 180 degrees with the samosas still in the pot, then fry until browned, about 8 minutes.
Remove samosa to dish and repeat until all samosas are cooked.

Diary.Content: When deep frying these for the first time (initially I tried to bake them), I tried a couple of different temperatures as they aren't specified in the original recipe. As far as I could glean from my limited notes, I always used 180 degrees for the second, high heat, fry. It looks like for the low heat, the first batch was on 150-160 and was too hot (caused bubbling), the second was 130 and the third and final batch was 140 (but then "accidentally to 155", assuming I left the heat increasing by accident). Unsure if 130 was too low or if I just wanted to try something different for 3rd batch.
Trying a double batch today. A note from previous times that there's usually too much filling, not addjusting for that today though.
Used an extra 4 tbsp of water in the dough (note double batch)
Only using half the ground coriander, feels like an excessive amount including the seeds.
Only using 3tbsp veg oil for spices so far.
Splitting the dough into 15 pieces, 64 grams apiece. Could also have done 12 pieces at 80 grams. Would be nice if they were bigger next time, but I want quantity this time.
Nevermind, 14 pieces it is, change one thing at a time etc.

Recipes.Name: Thai Beef Salad
Recipes.Note: From Recipe Tin Eats via Claudia via her dad. Has a very fresh flavour, lots of citrus.

Steps.Content: Pat steak dry with paper towel, rub salt and pepper into both sides.
In small jar add dressing ingredients. Use the garlic mincer.
Julienne carrot and cucumber into thick matchsticks, halve (if not already) and thinly slice the onion. Halve the cherry tomatoes. Leave all aside.
Heat oil in pan until smoking, fry steak for 2.5 minutes per side.
Remove steak to plate, loosely cover with foil and rest for 10 minutes.
Add lettuce to bowl and pour in a small portion of dressing to soak into it.
Roughly chop peanuts. If salted, rub the salt off with a tea towel.
Slice steak thinly (6mm) against grain.
Toss together all ingredients besides peanuts, then sprinkle some peanuts over top. Serve with the remaining peanuts in a small bowl.

Diary.Content: Previously did this with lime juice from a bottle. I also maybe used both fresh lemon juice and bottled lime juice in the dressing, unsure if a typo or not.

Recipes.Name: Mexican Red Rice
Recipes.Note: From the Fireworks Foods website, under Arroz a la Mexicana in all capital letters. Their website's top banner is a flame gif on loop. I haven't got this recipe quite right yet. It's definitely a side, but I've just been pretending it's a main and eating that, it's yum.

Steps.Content: In large bowl add the rice, and hot water to cover. Stand for 10 minutes, then drain and rinse well in cold water, then drain again.
Heat oil on high heat in large pot, then add rice and stir into the oil. Fry until the colour changes.
Roughly chop the tomatoes, onion and garlic then blend until smooth.
Add puree to pot and continue cooking over high heat until the mixture is dry.
Dice the carrot into small pieces.
Add the carrot, peas, stock and salt. Stir well and then reduce heat to medium and cover.
Cook until liquid has been absorbed and the surface has air holes across it.
Loosen rice with a fork before serving.

Diary.Content: added an extra tomato, did a whole small onion, did like 4 cloves garlic, only a quarter cup oil, let the rice sit in hot water for closer to 12 min, went harder on the rice frying stage. Still frying rice but no colour change yet. Maybe starting to yellow. Will stop soon. Rice is now definitely a little off white, and has feels in the pan closer to when it is dry out of the packet, not sticking and not clumping. Didnt drain the oil. Cooked on medium covered, but the sauce actually separated from the rice into a ring around top edge. Yummy but I dont think as much as last time, maybe too tomatoey? Not as chicken brothy.

Recipes.Name: Oat Sultana Cookies
Recipes.Note: From \href{https://www.amaltesepantry.com/oat-sultana-cookies/}{A Maltese Pastry}, though they attribute it to an instagram story on the Ottolenghi page and specifically credit Verna Lochmuller. This version of the recipe contains mistakes, including forgetting to add half the ingredients it calls for, notably the sultanas are never used in this sultana cookie recipe. I've made some substitutions because they were initially quite crunchy. Less sugar and lower cooking time. The jury is out on how long I should leave them on the tray before transferring to rack, next time.

Steps.Content: Place first lot of butter (@200 grams) into a small saucepan on medium heat. Cook for 5-7 minutes until browned, stirring frequently. It should foam and then turn dark brown.
In large mixing bowl, add the sugars, ground almond, salt, vanilla and remaining @75 grams of butter. Pour browned butter in and then stir well and cool for 10 minutes.
Add egg and whisk mixture.
Add oats, flour, baking powder, bi-carb, cinnamon, nutmeg and sultanas. Mix again, then cover with gladwrap and rest in fridge for 2 hours.
Preheat oven to 170 degrees conventional.
Measure 40 gram balls of dough. Place on tray lined with baking paper, plenty of room around them. Squash completely flat and tidy the sides.
Bake each tray for 10 minutes, then cool on tray for 3 minutes, then remove to cooling rack.

Diary.Content: Did several batches as though running a science experiment. Arrived at 170 degrees being best, but didn't actually write much down about the results, just the conditions. First tray 180 degrees, 10 min, 3 min on tray then to rack (still crunchy). Second tray 170 degrees, 10 min, but placed on upper rack of oven, 3 min on tray ("delicious", still crunchy). Third tray 170 degrees, 10 min, upper rack, 10 min on tray, rolled edge inward (no notes). Fourth tray 170 degrees, 10 min, upper rack, moved to cooling rack right away, no rolled edge (no notes). Fifth tray 170 degrees, 10 min, upper rack, 3 min on tray, strongly rolled edge (no notes). Assuming 3 min on tray is good, and rolled edge is maybe good. Also messed up browning the butter.

Recipes.Name: Prawn Risotto
Recipes.Note: None of the timing is specified, and the mix of different stocks is because that's what I had in the fridge. Nonetheless a very easy way to have a risotto.

Steps.Content: Thaw prawns in colander under running water.
Dice onion reasonably finely, slice garlic thinly.
Saute onions in pan for a few minutes.
Add garlic and fry for a few more minutes.
Add arborio, fry until rice is sticking.
Add white wine, fry it off.
Add stocks bit by bit.
Roughly chop parsley
Cook until stock is absorbed, then stir in the prawns and parsley.

Recipes.Name: Rugelach
Recipes.Note: Recipe from Claudia by email. A lot of time spent rolling them up but it should be noted that it's also a lot of fun to roll them up. Alternative fillings, in theory, are pecans, vanilla, chocolate, almond, caramel, strawberry. I'm told this flavour is the classic though. When making the dough, it's only split into 3 steps because I have a small food processor, it should all be done at once.

Steps.Content: Roughly dice both butter and cream cheese (1.5cm).
A third of each at a time, pulse the flour and salt, then incorporate the butter and cream cheese. On the final thirds, add the egg yolk with the butter and cream cheese.
Combine the pieces of dough on a floured bench. It should be moistened and crumbly with pea-sized curd-like pieces.
Knead dough until it comes together.
Split dough into 4 pieces, flatten each into 2 cm thick discs, wrap in clingfilm and refrigerate for an hour.
Pulse filling ingredients in food processor until walnuts are finely chopped.
Preheat oven to 175 degrees conventional, line trays with baking paper.

Remove dough from fridge. Working witth one piece at a time, dust with flour and roll to 3 mm thick. Spread 0.5 cup of filling over the dough, taking care to distribute evenly. Gently press the filling into the dough with fingertips.
With a sharp knife, cut the prepared circle into 16 wedges.
Roll each wedge from the outer edge toward the centre of the circle, applying even tension. No need to roll extremely tightly. Gently press tip of wedge into itself to seal.
Place wedges onto baking tray and bake until lightly golden (30 minutes), rotating at halfway. Cool on rack.
Repeat with remaining dough.

Diary.Content: Did some experiments with filling. One batch was pecan (generous 0.33 cup, 44g), 1 was pecan (generous 0.25 cup 20g) and walnut (0.25 cup 22g) and 2 were walnut (0.25 cup, 40g each). As a note on weights, 1/8 cup of brown sugar is 16 grams. So to make each batch added the nuts and then 16g brown sugar, 1.5tsp white sugar and 1tsp cinnamon, then transferred each to food processor and back to bowl.

Recipes.Name: Tomato Soup
Recipes.Note: I think this came from Claudia and I wanting to make tomato soup and not finding any good recipes. There was presumably a third of a capsicum sitting in the fridge. This is a very tart tomato soup. Basil quantity is made up, do whatever. Actually the whole recipe is made up, double do whatever.

Steps.Content: Preheat oven to 200 degrees conventional
Halve garlic head across.
Place tomatoes and garlic on oiled tray and grind over salt and pepper. Bake for 60 minutes.
Quarter onion and carrot, cut capsicum into 2 cm strips. Place on tray, toss with oil, salt and pepper and bake for 40 minutes.
On medium heat in a large pot, fry 8 tbsp tomato paste for a minute or two.
Add all roast vegetables to pot, including pan oil. Squash lightly.
Add @2 cups of water, @1.5 tsp salt and @2 tsp pepper. Simmer for 15 minutes.
Add basil leaves then blend with immersion blender.
Simmer for another 15 minutes.

Recipes.Name: Baked Beans
Recipes.Note: I lied - there is no oven. Called dad before cooking to ask how to imitate his baked beans, happy with the result. Very tasty over crumbly toast with lots of butter.

Steps.Content: Dice onion and bacon into small pieces, 8mm. Slice garlic thinly. Drain liquid from beans.
In a large pot on medium-high heat, fry onion and bacon in oil for a few minutes until edges are browned, 5 minutes.
Add garlic and tomato paste, fry for a minute or two.
Add beans and stock, balance with salt and pepper. Cook for 7 minutes or so until dry and sauce clings to beans. Now is a good time to put some bread in the toaster.

Diary.Content: Did 2 large onions and I think that's probably too much. Taking a long time to fry done, giving them 6 minutes and then I'll proceed.
I'm also doing it without bacon today, will see how that goes.
Delicious but maybe a little wetter than usual, and the bacon definitely adds to it.

Did it without bacon again, used 1 very  large onion and 4 large cloves of garlic. Red kidney beans instead. And for tomato paste I had double concentrate from a tube. I burnt it by while doing dishes and it ended up tasty. The texturee of the red kidney beans isn't as satisfying in this.

Recipes.Name: Split Pea Soup
Recipes.Note: Guanciale is a very fun word to say, and I think it makes the deli think you're clever. Unfortunately I didn't think it tasted that impressive. Warning that this recipe is a work in progress, it came out too salty and a bit too much in a general undefinable way.

Steps.Content: Peel swede and onion and chop both finely. Slice @4 cloves garlic thinly, dice the other one as finely as possible.
Remove skin from guanciale and chop into cute 1 cm pieces.
On medium heat in a large pot fry guanciale until fat pools in the pot, 10 minuets.
Remove guanciale and set aside in bowl, leaving oil in pot.
Add onions, the first 4 cloves of garlic, salt and pepper to pot and saute on medium-high until lightly browned for 5 minutes.
Add swede to pot, fry until tender, 10 minutes.
Add split peas, stock and bay leaf. Bring to strong simmer then reduce heat and simmer for 50 minutes until swede is falling apart.
Squash swede against side of pot a little during cooking.
Add grated garlic and remove from heat.
Serve by ladling soup into bowl and topping with guanciale and parsley, with a splash of oil and lemon juice.

Diary.Content: I used only half an onion and a mix of 5.75 cups chicken stock and 1.75 cups vegetable stock. I wrote that I should have simmerred for longer, that the end result is too salty and that the guanciale was better raw. Next time, I should cook without meat at all. Not sold on treating the garlic separately.

Cooking this tonight w/o guanciale. Using 2 small swedes and 1 very big onion, both feel like too much but I don't know how it's supposed to be. Took me 22 minutes to dice the veggies up. Would be a real time saver if I didn't need to do them so fine.
Planning to skip all the interim salt and pepper adding and just do it at the end, for fear of over salting like last time.
Gave the onions 6 min instead of 5.
Giving the swede some extra time to because after 10 min it doesn't seem to be tender. 12 minutes.
Simmering the whole lot for an extra 10 minutes too, still not falling apart.

As described above turned out pretty nice. I think the flavour I didn't like might actually just be chicken stock, but it seems to get tastier as it cooks. Roughly cracked pepper is very delicious. Next time, I'd consider using some water instead of some stock, and separately, potato instead of swede. Maybe this could become an easy meal? I'd also like to try cutting everything a bit larger to save on prep time.

Recipes.Name: Roast Vegetable Pies
Recipes.Note: Made this up vaguely in an attempt to recreate a tasty veggie pie I bought at a small food truck at the top of a waterfall somewhere I forget the name of. We bought the pies, went down the steps to the bottom of the waterfall, wandered about then climbed back up the stairs. The baker kept the pies warm in the oven for us the whole time. Substitute thyme for a few sprigs of fresh rosemary, roughly chopped. I've finally cracked using the pie cutter, line up the sheets side to side with a little overlap, cut all the bases you want, edge to edge alternating top/bottom of sheet, then make the tops out of the scraps.

Steps.Content: Preheat oven to 200 degrees conventional.
Chop potatoes (small chunks), carrots (quarter lengthwise).
On oven tray (or two) toss potatoes and carrots in oil, salt and pepper then roast for 1 hour.
Cut pastry sheets into pie cases, assemble and leave in fridge until time to cook.
Dice onions (1.5cm squares), thinly slice garlic.
Melt butter in large pot over medium-high heat. Add onions and fry for 4 minutes.
Add garlic and fry for another 1 minute.
Add thyme to pot and fry for 30 seconds.
Add flour to pot and stir very thoroughly, fry stirring until lightly browned, 4 minutes.
Add red wine and fry off briefly.
Add beef stock, water, salt and pepper. Flavour can be over intense because it will soon be combined with the veggies.
5 minutes after adding stock, add worcestershire sauce and stir well.
Simmer pot until sauce thickens, stirring.
Remove vegetables from oven, roughly chop carrots into cubes, then add potatoes, carrots and peas to sauce.
Place pie cases in pie maker, spoon in filling, place cover and cook for 14 minutes until deep brown.

Recipes.Name: Pecan Coffee Cake
Recipes.Note: Apparently a coffee cake is either a coffee flavoured cake, or a cake of any flavour made to be eaten with coffee. The recipe is from \href{https://www.allrecipes.com/recipe/246868/pecan-sour-cream-coffee-cake/}{All Recipes}, but I got it from my statistics lecturer who made this and several other cakes for his office to celebrate his birthday. I got lucky and walked past at the right time, and I later emailed to get the recipe. To get the halves even, I measured the batter and topping and did it by weight. The reason for the difficulty rating is that the measurements are super finicky. To get the brown sugar and flour quantities right, use a small spoon and fill up the larger measurement gradually, without packing it in.

Steps.Content: Measure the pecans and lay them all out on biggest cutting board. Using largest knife, chop the pile across over and over until pieces are small.
Preheat oven to 175 conventional.
Melt the smaller portion of butter on the stove.
Mix all crumb ingredients together very thoroughly, 4 minutes.
In a large bowl, mix the flour, baking powder, bi-carb and salt.
In a mixer, add the butter and sugar and blend well.
Add the eggs, blend well. Then add the flour mixture and blend until only just incorporated, don't over mix.
Butter a large, deep baking tray suitable for serving this in.
Place half of the cake mixture into the dish and spread as evenly as possible. Then sprinkle half of the topping across and push it into the cake very gently.
Pour the remaining cake mixture into the centre of the dish and spread it out like you would spread sauce on a pizza. Sprinkle over the remaining topping.
Bake until skewer tests clean, 45 minutes. Cool for 10 minutes.

Diary.Content: Did more time than the recipe suggests. Measured half of each mixture using a scale but the top rose much more, it also rose more in the middle than at the edges. Put the batter on as one big lump insstead of lots of little pieces, much easier.

Recipes.Name: Sweet Potato Shepherds Pie
Recipes.Note: After making this thoroughly UK feeling dinner, I sat and ate it infront of an episode of Are You Being Served. I measured the cheese but that's because initially I was putting it into the mash. Could add carrots. Consider putting a tray underneath in the oven to catch any oil.

Steps.Content: Peel sweet potato, wash the normal potatoes. Roughly cube both.
Place both potatoes in a pot, cover with water and boil until skewer tender.
Dice onion moderately finely, 8mm. Slice garlic thinly.
On medium-high heat in a large frying pan, fry onion in oil until lightly brown, 5 minutes.
Add garlic and tomato paste to frying pan, fry 2 min.
On slightly higher heat, add mince, a splash of water and spices. Fry until just browned, then reduce heat slightly and add worcestershire sauce, stir thoroughly.
Fry until it smells good, about 10 minutes. Just before finished, add the peas.
Preheat oven to 200 degrees conventional.
Mash potatoes, add butter, salt and pepepr to taste, as well as the milk.
Pour mince into large baking dish and even out, spoon the mash over it and then top with desired cheese.
Bake until yum, 50 minutes.

Recipes.Name: Fried Noodles
Recipes.Note: From \href{https://thewoksoflife.com/cantonese-soy-sauce-pan-fried-noodles}{The Woks Of Life}. I wanted noodles but really crispy and I tried googling it and that's literally a thing which is such great news. For spreading the noodles in the pan, my pan is definitely a lot smaller than their wok, which is why I break up the noodles a little before adding them back to the pan, else it's unmanageable.

Steps.Content: Fill a medium pot with enough water to submerge the noodles, bring the water to a boil.
Rinse bean sprouts in cold water and drain. Cut the spring onions into 2 inch julienned sticks.
Mix sauce ingredients in small bowl.
Boil the noodles for 1 minute, rinse in cold water and drain well.
Heat @1 tbsp of oil on high heat in a large frying pan. Add the noodles in an even layer. Tilt the pan to coat them in oil, then fry until crispy on bottom, 4 minutes.
Flip noodles and add another @1 tbsp of oil around the outside, tilt pan again. Fry until crunchy and a fair bit dried out, 2 minutes. Set aside.
Still on high heat, add another tablespoon of oil and then the white parts of the spring onions. Fry for 15 seconds.
Break up the noodles a little bit, then add them to the frying pan and continue breaking them up. Add the sauce and toss well for 2 minutes.
Add the bean sprouts and rest of the spring onions and toss again until the bean sprouts just start to turn transparent, still crunchy. 1 minute. Remove and plate.

Diary.Content: Followed the recipe pretty closely. Should maybe do less noodles next time as pan is very full. Flipped after 4 instead of 5 minutes because they started to burn, I added some extra oil too. Forgot rice wine.

Recipes.Name: Chicken Mole Negro
Recipes.Note: Chocolate chicken. In the lead up to cooking this I had to convince several people that this was a real thing. Bought the mole negro from Fireworks Foods in North Rocks. Got the vague recipe plan from the person serving, though there was no pretense of authenticity, she was just scheming to cook the whole thing in one pot. The veggies are an addition because they were in the fridge, but they really do brighten up the meal. Such a fun thing to eat. The steps are probably overkill but it's what I ended up with, I put the chicken in I put the chicken out I put the chicken in and I shake it all about.

Steps.Content: Wash chicken under water and pat dry.
In large pot on medium-high heat warm oil and then add chicken flat in a single layer. Sear until well browned then flip and repeat. If not enough room, do the chicken in batches and remove to plate.

Make the rice inbetween other steps. Add the rice and water to a medium pot, on medium heat bring to simmer then cover, reduce heat and cook for 13 minutes. Remove pot from heat and sit for 10 minutes, then remove lid, fluff and let sit for 2 minutes.
Blend diced tomatoes in food processor.
Remove chicken from pot and add diced tomatoes, simmer for 2 minutes.
Add chicken stock, reduce heat to medium and cook for 5 minutes.
Chop the onion and capsicum into strips and fry in a little oil in a separate frying pan.
Add chicken to pot, cover and cook for 10 minutes. Remove cover and cook for another 10 minutes.

Remove chicken again, then add mole negro. Stir very thoroughly to ensure all clumps are broken up, it's a very strong flavour. Remove from heat to stir further if needed, overheating supposedly breaks down the chocolate and bad things happen.
Place chicken back in pot, baste with sauce and serve with rice and vegetables.

Recipes.Name: Lemon Butter
Recipes.Note: From Stephanie Alexander's The Cook's Companion. I don't have my grandma's recipe but this tastes similar and she would often have a little red lidded jar in the fridge to use on toast. I recently found exactly the same jar at an op-shop in the free pile. On the same trip a day later I found another identical jar, they must be from some product and there are some icons in the lid but nothing I can put together. The steps are simple but measuring out and preparing the ingredients takes time. I also may have been cooking it at too low a temperature out of fear.

Steps.Content: Zest both lemons, should yield ~@2 tbsp.
Juice both lemons.
Whisk the eggs in a bowl and then push through a strainer.
In a small or medium pot on low heat, melt the butter.
Add the lemon juice, lemon zest and sugar. Stir constantly until sugar has dissolved.
Remove from heat, stir in eggs and then return to low heat. Stir constantly until mixture has thickened. Do not allow it to boil or it will curdle.
Wash jars in soap and then place in warm oven until ready to pour.
Pour mixture into jars and seal.

Diary.Content: I strained the eggs very carefully and the effect was magical. I also strained the lemon juice but I don't think I needed to. The recipe adds the butter with all the other ingredients but it took ages to melt so I figure melting first a good move. I took 25 minutes just for the cooking after adding the egg, but I think I was cooking on way too low a heat. By the end of it, I had it on the bottom-right burner at 6.5, I reckon I should have started with that. Made 3 little jars and was fantastic in colour, flavour and consistency.

Recipes.Name: Scones
Recipes.Note: From the Commonsense Cookery Book, my copy is the centenary edition, a birthday present years ago from Dad. His note in the front makes deliberate mention of the pandemic to anchor it in time. The cooking time is a lot longer than it should be because my oven is lazy at times. I tried to shape them like hamburger patties but I'll cut them from here on. Serve warm with lemon butter and thickened cream. The book instructs you to tear them open rather than cutting with a knife, thems the rules.

Steps.Content: Preheat oven to 240 degrees conventional.
Into large bowl sift flour and salt.
Dice butter and rub into flour mix lightly.
Reserving a little for glazing, pour the milk into the mixture and mix quickly into a soft dough. Don't overwork.
Turn onto floured bench and knead lightly and quickly, then roll out to a 2 cm thick round.
Cut with a sharp floured knife. Can cut 8 pieces like a pizza, squared or use a round cookie cutter.
Arrange close together on baking tray, glaze with milk and bake for 14 minutes.

Diary.Content: My notes are pretty much in the main recipe note. I haven't tried cutting them but assume that would work better. The original recipe gives a temperature range 230-260 degrees and a time range 8-10 minutes, so maybe I should use a higher heat next time.

Recipes.Name: Lamb Korma
Recipes.Note: From \href{https://nishkitchen.com/lamb-korma/}{Nish Kitchen}, who's delightful slogan is "A Delicious Adventure!". I tried to make this after buying some for lunch at Tandoori Connection.

Steps.Content: Make rice. Add rice and water to a pot on medium-high heat, bring to simmer then reduce to medium-low and cover. Cook for 13 minutes, then remove from heat and leave for 10 minutes. Finally, remove lid and fluff rice, leave for 2 minutes.
Chop onion roughly, slice garlic and ginger finely.
On medium high heat in oil, fry onion until softened, 5 minutes.
Add ginger and garlic, fry until fragrant.
Add cinnamon stick, bay leavves, red chilli, nutmeg, cumin, garam masala. Fry for another few seconds.
Add lamb, fry for 3 minutes.
Mix together the yoghurt and water, add to pot and cover. Bring to a boil, reduce heat to medium and simmer for 20 minutes.

Diary.Content: Both times I've made it, the amount is kind of awkward, just not quite 4 serves. Should serve with paratha, goes so deliciously.

Recipes.Name: Buffalo Chicken
Recipes.Note: Calling this a roast is a stretch. This recipe is from a TikTok meal prepper via Claudia. In the spirit of meal prepping, this is best enjoyed in a tupperware container as pictured.

Steps.Content: Preheat oven to 200 degrees conventional.
Dice potatoes into 1.5 cm cubes. Finely chop parsley. Toss potatoes with oil, the parsley and half of the dry spices (@1.5 tsp of each). Bake for 1 hour, flipping every 15 minutes.
Dice tomatoes, red onion and cucumber into 1 cm cubes. Slice spring onions then combine all salad ingredients in a medium bowl, squeezing the lemon juice over top.
Combine sauce ingredients in a small bowl.
Dice chicken breast into 1.5 cm cubes and toss in bowl with oil, sriracha and remaining spices.
Add oil to a frying pan on high and fry the chicken in @3 batches for 5 minutes. Shake it around but give it time to brown.

Diary.Content: Making tonight wiht more 1kg potato and 750g chicken breast. Next time I want 1kg of each and I think I'll get chicken thigh.
Using 4 tomatoes. Baking the chicken instead of frying. No sriracha on potatoes, lots of parsley and 100% of it is on the potatoes.
Half the sriracha in the sauce.
Did potatoes, then salad, then sauce and now moving on to chicken.
Diced the chicken fairly small. Again halved the sriracha. 50ml but weighed in at 44 grams so either way is fine. Frying it after all, high heat in stainless steel pan.
and in small batches.
with lots of oil.
Bumped heat up to max. Doing 3 batches. I reckon I put too much oil.
Took potato out 8 min early. Fried each batch of chicken for 5 min on max. Forgot spring onions entirely. Delicious.

Recipes.Name: White Bread
Recipes.Note: A constant work in progress to make bread that works for sandwiches. Mostly appropriated from The Commonsense Cookery Book. Every time I make it I come up with something I should change for the next time. The 15 minutes of kneading is long enough that I usually take a little break in the middle, but it is usually a really pleasant activity.

Steps.Content: In a large bowl combine dry ingredients and stir.
Measure out hot water (40 degrees) and mix until the dry mixture.
Pour a small pile of extra flour (@4-@6 tbsp) onto the bench and then turn mixture out and knead, incorporating flour little by little as needed. Knead for 15 minutes.

Pour oil around the sides of a large bowl and use your hand to coat the bowl. Place dough into it and then turn over so top is coated in oil. Run a teatowel through hot water, wring out and then cover bowl with it. Rise until doubled, 1 hour.
Preheat oven to 230 conventional, boil a kettle.
Knock back and knead dough for 1 minute.
Shape dough and lower into floured bread tin, cover again and rise for 20 minutes.
Place cake dish in oven and fill with boiling water.
After second rise, bake the loaf for 30 minutes.

Diary.Content: Felt like too much water but ended up really supple and slightly sticky. Next time I should score it diagonally three times after shaping, before the second rise. First rise went really fast, doubled in 30 minutes.

Organised the timings around a meeting. Used 3.5 tbsp of flour while kneading, gave it an 80 minute second rise, got big and texture looks nice, but there are some large bubbles. Baked for more like 35 minutes, and it never got to a point of knocking hollow in the middle, though it did at the edges. Didn't score it this time either. Next time I should bake it all the way until it knocks hollow.

Recipes.Name: Cauliflower Soup
Recipes.Note: From \href{https://cookieandkate.com/creamy-roasted-cauliflower-soup-recipe}{Cookie and Kate}. The first time I cooked it, I was prepared ahead of time, starting making the accompanying bread in the morning, had it timed out to go into the oven before I started a meeting, and come back out in time for me to make the soup, because Claudia was only home for a 30 minute window after work. Right as my meeting started, we had a full power outage and the bread just had to sit in the oven doing nothing. I still tried to bake it later and the result was delicious and chewy, but only about 4 cm tall. Anyway, I had an unlimited amount of time to prepare everything because I couldn't cook without electricity. Independently of that, the evening's plans got changed around and I then also had an unlimited amount of time to do the cooking part too. A really pleasant meal to take your time with. A note that blending it bit by bit gives it a fantastic texture that I can't get with our cheap immersion blender.

Steps.Content: Preheat oven to 220 degrees conventional.
Split cauiflower into florets and halve all but the smallest ones.
Toss in oil and salt on tray, place cut side down and bake for 30 minutes, turning after 15 minutes.
Dice onion into medium pieces, 1.5 cm. Slice garlic thinly.
To a large pot on medium heat in oil, add the onion and some salt. Fry until translucent, 7 minutes.
Add the garlic and fry for 30 seconds.
Remove cauliflower from oven, reserve 4 cute pieces to a bowl.
Add the remaining cauliflower and the stock, increase heat to medium-high and until it starts to simmer, then knock heat down until it is simmering gently. Cook for 20 minutes.
Working in batches, transfer the soup to a food processor and blend thoroughly.
Once all processed, add the nutmeg and ~@1 tbsp of lemon juice. Mix and adjust for more salt, pepper or lemon juice. Serve by garnishing with one of the stashed florets.

Diary.Content: As of uploading, this recipe is just based on the original website and my memmory of cooking it atleast a month ago, I forgot to make any notes.

Recipes.Name: Dal
Recipes.Note: From \href{https://www.thedeliciouscrescent.com/dal-recipe/}{The Delicious Crescent}, but I also asked young Laxsmi from the college kitchen while I was visiting Mik. The original version has options for either a restaurant or home style tadka. Don't discard the oil in the frying pan, my impression is that that is the whole point of tadka, to infuse the flavours into the oil.

Steps.Content: Finely dice onion and first lot of garlic. Moderately dice tomato.
Heat oil in a large pot on medium-high. Add lentils, onion, garlic, tomato, water and turmeric. Bring to a boil, then reduce heat to simmer for 30 minutes.
Slice remaining @5 cloves garlic thinly.
In medium frying pan heat vegetable oil on medium high. Add seeds and fry until they splutter, 1 minute.
To pan, add garlic and whole chillis, saute until garlic changes colour, 1 minute. Remove from heat.
When dal has simmered, use a potato masher to break up the contents.
Then, add the tadka, including pan oil, to the pot and simmer for a further 10 minutes, mashing again to achieve a nice consistency.

Diary.Content: Next time I should simmer for longer, either by adding more water or simmering with the lid on for some portion. I should also try scaling it up to 4 servings worth.
Making tonight. Probably takes closer to an hour all things considered. Sliced garlic instead of dicing. Everything else by the book.
Gave the first simmer more like 40 minutes, but it is getting a little dry so perhaps lid on would be a good move.

Recipes.Name: Lamb Tagine
Recipes.Note: From \href{https://www.slowcookerclub.com/slow-cooker-lamb-tagine/}{The Slow Cooker Club}, this was the first thing I used our slow cooker for. I woke up early and prepared everything, and then very excitingly left the house for class and let it cook away with no-one home. It was sufficiently exciting that I announced it to the class when I started the lesson.

Steps.Content: Roughly chop onions. Quarter carrots lengthwise and then chop into dice.
Trim any enormous pieces of fat from lamb and then chop into 3 cm pieces.
Heat oil in a large frying pan on medium-high. Place lamb pieces in a single layer to sear. Rotate pieces to sear as much surface area as possible. Remove to slow cooker.
Add carrots and onions to pan and fry until edges are browned, then remove to slow cooker.
Add all other ingredients to slow cooker, stir well and cook on high for 4 hours.

About 35 minutes before you plan to eat, make rice. Add rice and water to a pot on medium-high heat, bring to simmer then reduce to medium-low and cover. Cook for 13 minutes, then remove from heat and leave for 10 minutes. Finally, remove lid and fluff rice, leave for 2 minutes.

Diary.Content: Seared the meat on higher heat than the recipe originally recommended, it only just fit in one pan, could probably be two batches. I could also up the meat content a whole bunch I think. I added bonus cranberries, but they were undetectable in the final thing, even when eaten by themselves. I did put it in the slow cooker at 9:13 and leave it there until nearly 17:00. I think that might be too much, the flavours melded together and all but individual ingredients no longer had any kick to them, maybe I could add some ingredients later next time.

Recipes.Name: Potato and Leek Soup
Recipes.Note: From \href{recipetineats.com/leek-and-potato-soup/#wprm-recipe-container-23935}{Recipe Tin Eats} who actually credit someone for this recipe and mention using stock instead of water to make it more modern. The original recipe emphasises not over-blending or the potato will make the texture gluey. Besides chopping the leeks, this is a really easy recipe to make.

Steps.Content: Wash leek and separate the white or pale green parts from the dark green parts. Discard the latter. Peel pale green bits and then slice into thin circles. Slice garlic thinly.
In a large pot on medium heat, melt the butter.
Add garlic and leek and saute for 10 minutes until softened.
Cut potatoes into 2 cm chunks then add to pot with stock and water. Bring to simmer (takes a while) then cover and reduce heat to a gentle simmer. Cook for 25 minutes.
Remove from heat and puree with immersion blender until just smooth, don't over puree.
Toast a bunch of bread.
And cream, as well as salt and pepper to taste.

Diary.Content: I used 3 leeks as instructed but ended up with 5 cups instead of 2, which is why I sauted for longer. I also used a pile more garlic but I think the garlic I was using wasn't very strong. The half stock half water is because I ran out of stock, but it came out fine. Very bland but I think that's the point of making a potato and leek soup. Probably could do without the cream.
Doing a smaller batch, 2 leeks, 0.75 kg potato, 2.25cup c stock and 2.25 cup water, 0.5 cup cream. I.e. 3 serves instead of 4. Still same 30g butter and 4cl garlic.
Used vegetable stock instead of chicken (by necessity).
Only 1.5 cups veg stock, made up the difference with more water.

Recipes.Name: Beef Chow Mein
Recipes.Note: Another \href{https://www.recipetineats.com/beef-chow-mein-noodles/}{Recipe Tin Eats} recipe. After cooking this I went to a friends housewarming and spotted yet another Recipe Tin Eats cookbook. This recipe gets to be almost too big for my frying pan. The flavour of beef mince feels out of place but I could definitely get used to it.

Steps.Content: In a medium pot, boil enough water to submerge noodles (don't put them in until boiling).
Julienne carrot, slice wombok into strips (4mm), chop spring onions into 3cm lengths separating white from green, dice garlic finely.
In a colander, wash and drain bean sprouts then pat dry.
In a small bowl add the cornflour and water, stir until clumps are gone. Add all other sauce ingredients and stir again.
Add noodles to boiling water for 1 minute, then remove to colander and rinse in cold water, then drain well.
Add canola oil to large frying pan on high heat. Add garlic and fry for 10 seconds.
Add beef and fry until brown, 5 minutes.
Add 1.5 tbsp of the sauce and the white part of the spring onions. Fry 2 minutes.
Crack egg into pan and quickly mix it through the beef until the egg is mostly cooked.
Add carrot and wombok. Fry until the wombok wilts, 2 minutes.
Add bean sprouts, noodles and sauce. Toss well for 1 minute.
Add remaining spring onions, toss for another 1 minute.

Diary.Content: Cooked for the first time tonight, and in rare form actually wrote it up same day delivery. Forgot to add pepper to the sauce. The egg is fun. Upped the sauce quantities so they're easier to measure.

Making tonight with iceberg lettuce instead of wombok, and probably only 1.5 cups. Also skipping bean sprouts and making it slow because trying to time it with arrival of housemate. Just discovered that combining water and cornflour is really easily done by swishing the water by moving the bowl in your hand.

Was delicious. Times are pretty accurate, not sure how long it took total, I think I could get it faster than 50 minutes but the chopping does take time. Removing bean sprouts didn't really diminish it at all for me, and iceberg lettuce was a fine wombok substitute I think.
I forgot to say, I used 250 grams noodles not 200 because the packet is 500 grams.
Starting now with same substitutions as above, will see how long it takes today.
I added the carrot, stirred, then added the wombok, rather than adding both simultaneously.
At times it felt I should turn the pan down but I didn't and now the beef is real crispy in a good way.
Stirred the noodles pretty thoroughly before starting the 1 minute timer.
Done
A note that in the above record setting time, I made the sauce while the beef was frying, which saved nearly 5 minutes but was a push to fit in.

Recipes.Name: Gnocchi Alla Sorrentina
Recipes.Note: From \href{https://www.maricruzavalos.com/gnocchi-alla-sorrentina/#recipe}{Maricruz Avalos}. I saw this recipe but looked at the other recipes on the site and thought I could find something more authentic. I arrived at an authentic recipe that opened with a rant against less authentic versions of the recipe, which snapped me right out of it. This one is delicious. Authentic. Authentic. Authentic. Authentic. Authentic. Authentic. Authentic. Authentic. Authentic. Authentic. Authentic. Authentic. Authentic. Authentic. Authentic. Authentic. Authentic. Authentic. Authentic. Authentic. Authentic. Authentic. Authentic. Authentic. Authentic. Authentic. Authentic. Authentic. Authentic. Authentic. Authentic. Authentic. Authentic. Authentic. Authentic. Authentic. Authentic. Authentic. Authentic. Authentic. I've had enough.

Steps.Content: Bring large pot of water to boil.
Preheat grill element of oven on high.
Slice garlic thinly, grate two thirds of the mozzarella coarsely and break the rest into cute little pieces.
Heat oil in another large pot on medium-high.
Add garlic, fry until fragrant, 10 seconds.
Add cherry tomatoes and fry until softened, 5 minutes. Towards the end, squash them just enough to make them burst.
Add passata, salt and pepper. Fry for a moment while you tear up basil leaves, reserving some whole ones for garnish later.
Add torn basil leaves, stir, reduce heat to low and simmer until thickened, 5 minutes.
Drop gnocchi into boiling water and drain all of them in colander once like 10 have risen to the surface, 2 minutes or so.
Add gnocchi and grated mozzarella to pan and stir well.
Transfer to stylish baking dish, arrange whole basil leaves and remaining mozzarella. Bake under grill until cheese melts, 4 minutes.

Diary.Content: Not convinced that 5 minutes was enough for the cherry tomatoes, the're not very softened. Seems fine but tomatoes are a little bit harder than I'd like. Needs more gnocchi relative to tomatoes. I think to balance the extra gnocchi I would use the whole jar of passata, and maybe more mozzarella. I could add more tomatoes but I don't think I will. Next time I should use a large pot instead of a frying pan.

Recipes.Name: Pizza Dough
Recipes.Note: From The Cook's Companion. 15 minutes is a really long time.

Steps.Content: In large bowl combine flour, yeast and salt.
Add water and oil to the dry ingredients and mix thoroughly.
Knead until smooth and elastic, 15 minutes by hand.
Grease large bowl with oil and place dough into it. Flip over, then cover with a damp teatowel.
Rise until doubled, 1.5 hours.
Knock back dough, split into @4 pieces, coover again.
Rise for 30-45 minutes.
Roll out and make pizza.

Diary.Content: Making a double batch for calzone. Used plain flour, didn't mix oil with water, combined ingredients with mixmaster dough hook and used that to knead aswell.

Kneaded by machine for 10 minutes then brought on a train then knocked back after an hour. Rising another 45 or so. Mum made a batch of Tony's pizza sauce with added garlic. Plan is chop some mushrooms and olives, stir them in, roll dough out thin, add filling and bake at like 240 fan for 20 min.

240 fan for 12 minutes. can roll a little bit thicker, doesn't look cute if you make it flat. Don't score, maybe make a little hole at top. Brush with oil. Next time, use mozzarella. Used 2 small onions in sauce, 6 mushrooms or a little less, and a handful of olives. maybe quarter cup. some garlic, a can of diced tomatoes. 1 tbsp tomato paste. 0.5 tsp dried oregano. salt and pepper. and oil.
